raw_text:
Fast moving phone bugs appear
 
 Security firms are warning about several mobile phone viruses that can spread much faster than similar bugs.
 
 The new strains of the Cabir mobile phone virus use short-range radio technology to leap to any vulnerable phone as soon as it is in range. The Cabir virus only affects high-end handsets running the Symbian Series 60 phone operating system. Despite the warnings, there are so far no reports of any phones being infected by the new variants of Cabir.
 
 The original Cabir worm came to light in mid-June 2004 when it was sent to anti-virus firms as a proof-of-concept program. A mistake in the way the original Cabir was written meant that even if it escaped from the laboratory, the bug would only have been able to infect one phone at a time.
 
 However, the new Cabir strains have this mistake corrected and will spread via short range Bluetooth technology to any vulnerable phone in range. Bluetooth has an effective range of a few tens of metres. The risk of being infected by Cabir is low because users must give the malicious program permission to download on to their handset and then must manually install it. Users can protect themselves by altering a setting on Symbian phones that conceals the handset from other Bluetooth using devices. Finnish security firm F-Secure issued a warning about the new strains of Cabir but said that the viruses do not do any damage to a phone. All they do is block normal Bluetooth activity and drain the phone's battery. Anti-virus firm Sophos said the source code for Cabir had been posted on the net by a Brazilian programmer which might lead to even more variants of the program being created. So far seven versions of Cabir are know to exist, one of which was inside the malicious Skulls program that was found in late November. Symbian's Series 60 software is licenced by Nokia, LG Electronics, Lenovo, Panasonic, Samsung, Sendo and Siemens.
llama3.2:1b:
Here is a concise summary of the text:

Security firms warn about new strains of mobile phone virus called Cabir, which can spread quickly via short-range radio technology (Bluetooth) to vulnerable phones in range. The virus affects high-end handsets running Symbian Series 60 operating system and has been linked to the original Cabir worm from mid-2004.
llama3.2:3b: Mobile phone viruses spread quickly through Bluetooth technology, affecting high-end handsets with Symbian Series 60 operating system. The Cabir virus has corrected the original mistake that limited its spread to one infected phone at a time, allowing it to infect vulnerable phones in range. The risk of infection is low due to user permission and manual installation requirements, but users can protect themselves by concealing their handset from other Bluetooth devices.
gemma2:2b: Mobile phone viruses called Cabir have been spreading rapidly using short-range Bluetooth technology. These new strains can infect phones running the Symbian Series 60 operating system, but they don't cause any damage; rather, they just block normal Bluetooth activity and drain phone batteries.  The virus was discovered after a programmer posted its source code online, leading to more variants.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Security firms warn about new mobile phone viruses known as Cabir. The Cabir virus uses short-range Bluetooth technology to spread quickly once it infects the targeted phone. It only affects high-end handsets running the Symbian Series 60 operating system. No reports of infections have been reported yet, but the company warns that users should take precautions to protect themselves from Cabir-related malware.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Security firms have warned about new strains of a Cabir virus spreading via short-range radio technology on high-end Symbian handsets running the Series 60 operating system. Despite warnings, no reported infections exist. The original Cabir was designed to infect one phone at a time but has been corrected to spread via Bluetooth. Users must manually download and install it. Bluetooth's effective range is several tens of meters, making infection risk low. F-Secure warned about the new strains, while Sophos noted that posting the source code might lead to more variants being created. Seven versions are known, including one in a malicious Skulls program found in November 2004. The virus blocks Bluetooth and drains phone batteries. Symbian licenses its software to major manufacturers.
qwen2.5:3b: Fast-moving mobile phone viruses using short-range radio technology have been identified, particularly affecting high-end phones with the Symbian Series 60 operating system. The Cabir virus variants correct a previous mistake that limited spread to one device at a time via Bluetooth, now spreading broadly within range. Users must manually install and enable permission for it. Security firms like F-Secure and Sophos warn of potential damage (blocking Bluetooth activity and draining battery) but no infections have been reported so far. The Cabir source code has also led to more variants possibly appearing. Symbian Series 60 is used by multiple manufacturers including Nokia, LG Electronics, Lenovo, Panasonic, Samsung, Sendo, and Siemens.
opencoder:1.5b: The new strains of Cabir mobile phone virus use short-range radio technology to spread rapidly through Bluetooth range. Despite the warnings, the virus will only infect high-end handsets running on Symbian Series 60 operating system. The virus can be used for spreading in a range of tens of meters due to short-range Bluetooth technology. However, as users must give permission and manual installation is required, providing the malicious program source code might lead to more variations of Cabir virus being created. Thus, no further strains are known to infect a phone with the new Cabir strains.

A mistake in the way the original Cabir was written meant that even if it escaped from the laboratory, the bug would only have been able to infect one phone at a time. However, the new Cabir strains have this mistake corrected and will spread via short range Bluetooth technology to any vulnerable phone in range. Bluetooth has an effective range of a few tens of meters. The risk of being infected by Cabir is low because users must give the malicious program permission to download on to their handset and then must manually install it. Users can protect themselves by altering a setting on Symbian phones that conceals the handset from other Bluetooth using devices. Finnish security firm F-Secure issued a warning about the new strains of Cabir but said that the viruses do not do any damage to a phone. All they do is block normal Bluetooth activity and drain the phone's battery. Anti-virus firm Sophos said the source code for Cabir had been posted on the net by a Brazilian programmer which might lead to even more variants of the program being created. So far seven versions of Cabir are known to exist, one of which was inside the malicious Skulls program that was found in late November. Symbian's Series 60 software is licenced by Nokia, LG Electronics, Lenovo, Panasonic, Samsung, Sendo and Siemens.

<think>
Okay, so I have this text about mobile phone viruses called Cabir. The user wants me to summarize it concisely, focusing on the key ideas and details. Let me read through the text first.

The original Cabir bug appeared in June 2004 as a proof of concept for an anti-virus firm. It infects one phone at a time because of a bug that wasn't secure. Now, new strains use short-range Bluetooth to reach any device in range and spread faster. Bluetooth has a longer range than radio tech.

They mention Symbian Series 60 phones using this, which are popular brands like Nokia, LG, Lenovo, etc. F-Secure warned about the risk but said the virus doesn't damage the phone; it just blocks Bluetooth and drains battery. Sophos is worried about more versions being created from a Brazilian programmer's source.

There were seven Cabir strains known by now, with one inside Skulls. Symbian's Series 60 phones are licensed in several countries. No reports of infection yet despite warnings.

I need to condense this into a summary without explanations or formatting. I'll list the main points: original appearance, short-range Bluetooth for spread, risk reduction by F-Secure warning, recent update about seven strains known, and Symbian's licensing status.
</think>

Fast-moving mobile phone viruses, Cabir, appeared in mid-June 2004 as a proof-of-concept program. They infect one phone at a time due to a bug that made them vulnerable. New strains use short-range Bluetooth to spread faster than radio tech. F-Secure warns low risk for Symbian Series 60 phones using it, which are licensed by major brands. Sophos worries more Cabir versions could emerge from a Brazilian programmer's source. Seven strains are known; one was found inside Skulls. No reports of infection despite warnings.
tinyllama:1.1b: Despite the warnings from security firms and anti-virus firms about new strains of the Cabir mobile phone virus, there are currently no reports of infections by the original Cabir or its newly corrected variant. The virus uses short-range radio technology to move quickly across phones as soon as they're in range, meaning that even if it was unable to spread via traditional methods like email or downloading software, it would only have infected one phone at a time. The new strains of Cabir are a proof-of-concept program and were originally written with the error correction but were corrected before being released into the wild as a Bluetooth threat. Despite this, users must still give the malicious program permission to download on their handsets, and they can prevent infection by altering a setting on their phones that conceals them from other Bluetooth devices. The virus also drains the battery of infected phones, but anti-virus firms have noted that all it does is block normal Bluetooth activity. Seven versions of Cabir exist, with the original version being inside the Skulls program found in late November. Symbian's Series 60 software is licenced by Nokia, LG Electronics, Lenovo, Panasonic, Samsung, Sendo and Siemens.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The text provided describes the emergence of several mobile phone viruses, specifically known as Cabir, that spread via short-range Bluetooth technology to infect victims' handsets. These viruses have been found to be very effective at spreading but also require users to grant permission for them to download and install on their devices. The new strains of Cabir are designed to appear much faster than similar virus variants, but without proper security measures in place, they can potentially do significant harm to infected phones. Symbian's Series 60 software is licensed by several companies including Nokia, LG Electronics, Lenovo, Panasonic, Samsung, and Siemens.

The original Cabir bug only infected one phone at a time, but the new strains can infect multiple phones. However, users can protect themselves by changing a setting on Symbian phones and anti-virus firms have issued warnings about these new viruses. They do not cause damage to the phone, but block normal Bluetooth activity and drain the battery. Seven versions of Cabir are known to exist, one of which was found in the malicious Skulls program.

The new strains of the Cabir mobile phone virus use short-range radio technology to leap to any vulnerable phone as soon as it is in range. The Cabir virus only affects high-end handsets running the Symbian Series 60 phone operating system. Despite warnings, there are no reports of any phones being infected by the new variants of Cabir. The original Cabir worm came to light in mid-June 2004 when it was sent to anti-virus firms as a proof-of-concept program. A mistake in the way the original Cabir was written meant that even if it escaped from the laboratory, the bug would only have been able to infect one phone at a time. However, the new Cabir strains have this mistake corrected and will spread via short range Bluetooth technology to any vulnerable phone in range. The risk of being infected by Cabir is low because users must give the malicious program permission to download on to their handset and then must manually install it. Users can protect themselves by altering a setting on Symbian phones that conceals the handset from other Bluetooth using devices. Anti-virus firm Sophos said the source code for Cabir had been posted on the net by a Brazilian programmer which might lead to even more variants of the program being created. So far, seven versions of Cabir are know to exist, one of which was inside the malicious Skulls program that was found in late November. Symbian's Series 60 software is licenced by Nokia, LG Electronics, Lenovo, Panasonic, Samsung, Sendo and Siemens.
hermes3:3b: Cabir mobile viruses spread quickly via Bluetooth, infecting high-end Symbian Series 60 phones; risks low due to user permission required for download.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Security firms have warned about fast-spreading mobile phone viruses, specifically the Cabir virus, which uses short-range radio technology to jump to vulnerable phones in range. The new strains of Cabir correct a mistake from the original worm, spreading via Bluetooth to any compatible phone within a few tens of meters. While these viruses do not damage phones but only block normal Bluetooth activity and drain battery power, users can protect themselves by altering their Symbian settings. Finnish firm F-Secure has issued a warning about the new Cabir strains, with anti-virus firm Sophos mentioning that the source code has been posted online, potentially leading to more variants of the program. Currently, seven versions of Cabir exist, including one found in the malicious Skulls program.
stablelm2:1.6b: Security firms warn about new mobile phone viruses that spread faster than previous bugs, such as Cabir. These newer strains use short-range radio technology and only affect high-end handsets with the Symbian Series phone operating system. Despite warnings, no reports of infection have been made public yet. The original Cabir virus was accidentally created but contained a mistake that prevented it from infecting multiple phones at once. However, the new versions have this issue corrected and can spread via short-range Bluetooth technology to any vulnerable phone in range. Users can protect themselves by altering settings on Symbian phones or blocking the malicious program's download through Bluetooth usage. granite3.1-dense:2b: Security firms are cautioning about faster-spreading variants of the Cabir mobile phone virus, which target high-end Symbian Series 60 phones. These new strains exploit short-range Bluetooth technology to infect any nearby vulnerable device when given permission and manually installed by users. Despite the risk, no infections have been reported yet due to users needing to enable Bluetooth and install the malware intentionally. The original Cabir, found in mid-2004, could only infect one phone at a time due to a coding error. However, this issue is corrected in the new variants. They mainly disable normal Bluetooth functionality and drain battery power but cause no damage. Seven known versions of Cabir exist, with one discovered within the Skulls program in late November 2004. Symbian Series 60 software is used by Nokia, LG Electronics, Lenovo, Panasonic, Samsung, Sendo, and Siemens. A Brazilian programmer posted the Cabir source code online, potentially leading to more variants.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Security firms warn of new Cabir mobile phone virus strains that spread rapidly via Bluetooth to vulnerable Symbian Series 60 phones. Unlike the original Cabir, which could only infect one phone at a time, the new variants can spread to any phone in range. However, infection requires user permission and manual installation. The virus does not damage phones but disrupts Bluetooth and drains batteries. Finnish security firm F-Secure and anti-virus firm Sophos caution that the virus's source code has been posted online, potentially leading to more variants. So far, seven versions exist, with one found in the Skulls malware. Symbian's Series 60 software is used by major phone manufacturers, including Nokia, Samsung, and Siemens.
